entry.title: Philosophy of Science Chi 2
entry.content:
Demarcating Science

Science
- Test Hypotheses against observations or experimental results
- base their conclusion on the evidence

A Pair of Distinctions

Context of discovery
Context of justification

::“Significant novel hypotheses rarely emerge from a mechanical compilation of data but often require the imaginative leap that introduces a new conception. If there are methods of discovery, they are not fully general, but limited to domains with particular features.”::

Analytic Truth

Mathematics VS natural Science

Mathematics :

  • analytic truths
  • deducing theorem from the axioms with logic

Natural Science :

  • hypotheses must be based on observation of nature
  • proving hypotheses by using basic statements as the premises in inferences that accord with the rules of an extended logic

Both consists in assembling basic statements and constructing arguments sanctioned by logic to ground conclusion about nature

Two questions:
What are the proper starting points for justificatory arguments in science?
What types of inference, beyond deduction, should be allowed in an “extended logic“ for science?

Revisability

Karl Popper
The mark of real science is falsifiability.
Good hypotheses stick their necks out; they take risks by making claims that nature could reject.

The openness to correction is the hallmark of science and the source of the superiority of science over other kinds of human knowledge

A bundle of hypotheses allow avoidance of criticism to the central claim which makes the hallmark of falsifiability of science pointless

Three main characteristics of natural sciences

Theory of confirmation
Theory of theories and theoretical language
Theory of explanation

Confirmation

Scientific evidence falls short of conclusive proof.
General hypotheses are subject to revision.
The scientific process does not prove but simply confirms.

How does it confirms?

The Hypothetico-Deductive Method
